results.name: Triangle read by rows: T(n,k) = number of partial derangements, that is, the number of permutations of n distinct, ordered items in which exactly k of the items are in their natural ordered positions, for n >= 0, k = n, n-1, ..., 1, 0.
comment: In other words, T(n,k) is the number of permutations of n letters that are at Hammimg distance k from the identity permutation (Cf. Diaconis, p. 112). - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Mar 02 2007

The sequence d(n) = 1, 0, 1, 2, 9, 44, 265, 1854, 14833, ... (A000166) is the number of derangements, that is, the number of permutations of n distinct, ordered items in which none of the items is in its natural ordered position.
link: Reinhard Zumkeller, Rows n = 0..125 of triangle, flattened
P. Diaconis, Group Representations in Probability and Statistics, IMS, 1988; see p. 112.

Chris D. H. Evans, John Hughes and Julia Houston, Significance-testing the validity of idiographic methods: A little derangement goes a long way, British Journal of Mathematical and Statistical Psychology, 1 November 2002, Vol. 55, pp. 385-390.
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Partial Derangement
formula: Assuming a uniform distribution on S_n, the mean Hamming distance is n-1 and the variance is 1 (Diaconis, p. 117). - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Mar 02 2007
example: Assume d(0), d(1), d(2) are given. Then
mathematica: t[0, 0] = 1; t[n_, k_] := Binomial[n, k]*k!*Sum[(-1)^j/j!, {j, 0, k}]; Flatten[ Table[ t[n, k], {n, 0, 10}, {k, 0, n}]] (* _Robert G. Wilson v_, Nov 04 2004 *)
